fields.title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
fields.author: Douglas Adams
fields.description: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams is a comedic science fiction novel that follows the misadventures of Arthur Dent, an ordinary human thrust into an extraordinary universe. After Earth is unexpectedly destroyed, Arthur finds himself aboard a spaceship alongside his eccentric friend Ford Prefect, who turns out to be an alien researcher for a galactic guidebook. Together, they embark on a surreal journey through space, encountering bizarre planets, peculiar alien species, and the enigmatic titular guide.

fields.title: The Hate U Give
fields.author: Angie Thomas
fields.description: The Hate U Give by Angie Thomas is a powerful and thought-provoking novel that tells the story of Starr Carter, a 16-year-old girl who navigates life between her predominantly Black, working-class neighborhood and the wealthy, mostly white private school she attends. Starr's world is upended when she witnesses the fatal police shooting of her unarmed best friend, Khalil, an event that thrusts her into the national spotlight and forces her to confront systemic racism, injustice, and her own identity.

fields.title: The Theory of Everything Else
fields.author: Dan Schreiber
fields.description: The Theory of Everything Else: A Voyage into the World of the Weird by Dan Schreiber is an intriguing exploration of strange ideas, unconventional theories, and the quirky edges of human curiosity. The book dives into a diverse range of topics—from conspiracy theories to bizarre scientific hypotheses—unearthing the most eccentric beliefs and oddities from history and modern times.

fields.title: The Culture Map
fields.author: Erin Meyer
fields.description: The Culture Map: Decoding How People Think, Lead, and Get Things Done Across Cultures by Erin Meyer is a practical and insightful guide to navigating the complexities of cross-cultural communication. Drawing from extensive research and real-world examples, Meyer breaks down how cultural differences influence the way people express ideas, give feedback, make decisions, and collaborate in professional settings.

fields.title: How To Get Over a Boy
fields.author: Chidera Eggerue
fields.description: How to Get Over a Boy by Chidera Eggerue is a bold and empowering guide for women navigating the emotional challenges of heartbreak and unfulfilling relationships. Drawing from personal experiences and a feminist perspective, Eggerue challenges societal norms that place excessive value on romantic relationships and encourages readers to reclaim their self-worth. The book explores themes of self-love, independence, and the importance of setting boundaries, offering practical advice for women to prioritize themselves rather than conform to harmful expectations about love and partnership.

fields.title: Everyone On This Train Is A Suspect
fields.author: Benjamin Stevenson
fields.description: Everyone On This Train Is A Suspect by Benjamin Stevenson is a clever and entertaining whodunit set aboard a luxurious train journey through the snowy Australian Alps. The story follows amateur sleuth Ernest Cunningham, who finds himself embroiled in a murder investigation when a passenger is killed under mysterious circumstances. As the train becomes snowed in, cutting off contact with the outside world, Ernest must unravel the clues and uncover the killer among a colorful cast of characters, each hiding their own secrets.

fields.title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
fields.author: Yuval Noah Harari
fields.description: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century by Yuval Noah Harari is a thought-provoking exploration of the challenges and opportunities facing humanity in an era of rapid technological, political, and social change. Harari delves into pressing topics such as artificial intelligence, climate change, the rise of nationalism, and the future of work, offering insights into how these forces are reshaping societies and individual lives. He invites readers to consider how to navigate these uncertainties by questioning traditional beliefs, embracing adaptability, and fostering critical thinking.

fields.title: The Body Keeps the Score
fields.author: Bessel van der Kolk
fields.description: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind, and Body in the Healing of Trauma by Bessel van der Kolk is a groundbreaking exploration of how trauma impacts the brain and body. Drawing on decades of research and clinical experience, van der Kolk reveals the profound effects of trauma on mental, emotional, and physical health. He explains how traumatic experiences can reshape the brain's wiring, leading to issues such as anxiety, depression, and dissociation, and how these experiences are often stored in the body, manifesting in various physical symptoms.

fields.title: The Alchemist
fields.author: Paulo Coelho
fields.description: The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho is a philosophical novel that follows the journey of Santiago, a young shepherd from Spain, as he seeks his personal legend and dreams of discovering treasure hidden in the Egyptian pyramids. Along the way, Santiago learns important life lessons about following his heart, overcoming obstacles, and understanding the interconnectedness of all things. The novel is rich with themes of self-discovery, destiny, and the pursuit of one's dreams, blending elements of adventure and spirituality.

fields.title: The Catcher in the Rye
fields.author: J.D Salinger
fields.description: The Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger follows Holden Caulfield, a disillusioned teenager who has just been expelled from his prestigious prep school. The novel chronicles Holden's journey through New York City as he struggles with the complexities of adolescence, alienation, and the loss of innocence. Narrated in a candid, stream-of-consciousness style, Holden reflects on his relationships, his fears of growing up, and his longing for genuine human connection.

fields.title: Doppelganger
fields.author: Naoimi Klein
fields.description: A Trip Into the Mirror World by Naomi Klein is a thought-provoking exploration of identity, disinformation, and the chaotic landscapes of modern politics. Klein begins with her personal experience of being mistaken for Naomi Wolf, another prominent author, whose views have sharply diverged into conspiracy theories and right-wing rhetoric. Using this case of mistaken identity as a springboard, Klein delves into the idea of 'mirror worlds'—parallel realities fueled by social media, polarization, and misinformation, where truth and fiction blur.

fields.title: The Song of Achilles
fields.author: Madeline Miller
fields.description: The Song of Achilles by Madeline Miller is a captivating retelling of the Greek myth of Achilles, narrated from the perspective of his closest companion, Patroclus. The novel follows their relationship from childhood, as the exiled Patroclus forms a deep bond with the golden, godlike Achilles, to their eventual romance. Set against the backdrop of the Trojan War, the story weaves themes of love, loyalty, and destiny as the two navigate the challenges of their fated roles in a world of gods and heroes.

fields.title: In Memoriam
fields.author: Alice Winn
fields.description: In Memoriam by Alice Winn is a poignant historical novel set during World War I, exploring the profound bond between two young men, Gaunt and Ellwood, who attend a prestigious English boarding school. The story begins with their idyllic life at school, but as war breaks out, they find themselves thrust into the brutal realities of the Western Front. Amidst the chaos and suffering, their friendship deepens into a forbidden and tender love, tested by the horrors of war and the societal expectations of their time.

fields.title: Boy Parts
fields.author: Eliza Clark
fields.description: Boy Parts by Eliza Clark is a darkly humorous and unsettling psychological novel that follows Irina, an unconventional and provocative photographer in contemporary London. Irina specializes in capturing explicit and often degrading portraits of men she picks up in bars and online, using her art as a form of control and expression. Beneath her sharp wit and confidence, however, lies a deeply troubled psyche, which begins to unravel when she is offered an exhibition of her work and forced to confront her past and the boundaries of her desires.

fields.title: The Gentleman from Peru
fields.author: Andre Aciman
fields.description: The Gentleman from Peru by André Aciman is a captivating novella about love, memory, and the blurred boundaries between reality and fantasy. Set in a luxurious Italian seaside resort, the story revolves around a mysterious Peruvian gentleman, Enrique, and a young woman, Nico, who becomes intrigued by his seemingly clairvoyant abilities. As their conversations deepen, Enrique reveals his power to see into people's thoughts and memories, drawing Nico into a hypnotic connection where past and present intermingle.

fields.title: The New Life
fields.author: Tom Crewe
fields.description: The New Life by Tom Crewe is a powerful historical novel set in late 19th-century England, exploring themes of love, identity, and societal change. The story follows two men, John Addington and Henry Ellis, who are drawn together by their shared passion for challenging the strict moral codes of Victorian society. Both men are involved in unconventional relationships—Addington with a younger male partner and Ellis in a marriage with a woman who desires her own freedom. As they collaborate on a groundbreaking book advocating for sexual and personal liberation, their private lives become intertwined with their political ideals.

fields.title: Great Expectations
fields.author: Charles Dickens
fields.description: Great Expectations by Charles Dickens is a coming-of-age novel that follows the life of Pip, an orphan raised by his sister and her blacksmith husband in the marshes of Kent. Pip's life changes when he encounters two enigmatic figures: an escaped convict who leaves a lasting impression on him and the wealthy, eccentric Miss Havisham, who introduces him to her beautiful but cold-hearted ward, Estella. Longing to rise above his humble beginnings and win Estella's love, Pip's fortunes shift dramatically when he receives an unexpected inheritance from a mysterious benefactor.

fields.title: The Odyssey
fields.author: Homer
fields.description: The Odyssey by Homer is one of the most famous epic poems of ancient Greece, telling the story of Odysseus’ long and arduous journey home after the Trojan War. The poem follows Odysseus as he encounters numerous challenges, including mythical creatures like the Cyclops, seductive sirens, and the vengeful sea god Poseidon. Throughout his voyage, Odysseus must rely on his wits, strength, and cunning to overcome obstacles while contending with the loss of his crew and the yearning to reunite with his wife, Penelope, and son, Telemachus.

fields.title: The Iliad
fields.author: Homer
fields.description: The Iliad by Homer is an ancient Greek epic that focuses on the events of the Trojan War, specifically the conflict between the Greek hero Achilles and King Agamemnon. The story begins with a dispute over a captured woman, Briseis, leading Achilles to withdraw from battle, which has dire consequences for the Greek forces. The poem delves into themes of heroism, pride, fate, and the wrath of gods as the characters grapple with honor, vengeance, and the inevitability of death.

fields.title: Cities of the Red Night
fields.author: William S. Burroughs
fields.description: Cities of the Red Night by William S. Burroughs is a surreal, experimental novel that blends science fiction, history, and Burroughs’ signature cutting-edge narrative style. The story spans multiple timelines and settings, from the age of piracy to a dystopian future, as it follows various characters entangled in bizarre and often violent events. At its core, the novel explores themes of control, sexuality, and the nature of power, with a focus on the intersection of political intrigue and human depravity.

fields.title: Big Sur
fields.author: Jack Kerouac
fields.description: Big Sur by Jack Kerouac is a semi-autobiographical novel that captures the author's struggle with fame, personal demons, and his search for peace in the rugged beauty of California’s Big Sur coast. The story follows Kerouac’s alter ego, Jack Duluoz, as he retreats to a cabin in Big Sur to escape the pressures of his rising literary fame and turbulent personal life. There, he confronts feelings of isolation, despair, and disillusionment, while seeking solace in nature and attempting to understand the meaning of his existence.

fields.title: Tracks
fields.author: Robyn Davidson
fields.description: Tracks by Robyn Davidson is a memoir that chronicles the author’s incredible journey across the Australian outback with her camels, a feat she undertook alone in the 1970s. Davidson recounts her 1,700-mile trek from Alice Springs to the Indian Ocean, a grueling and often dangerous adventure that tests her physical endurance and mental resilience. Along the way, she contends with isolation, the harsh landscape, and her own inner turmoil, while reflecting on themes of independence, self-discovery, and the complexities of human connection.

fields.title: This Is How You Lose the Time War
fields.author: Amal El-Mohtar and Max Gladstone
fields.description: This Is How You Lose the Time War by Amal El-Mohtar and Max Gladstone is a poetic and genre-defying novel about two time-traveling agents, Red and Blue, who work for opposing factions engaged in a cosmic battle across time and space. The two women are tasked with manipulating events throughout history to ensure the success of their respective sides, yet they begin to form an unlikely bond as they leave messages for each other through time, challenging their loyalties and beliefs. Their correspondence evolves into a deep and complex love affair, set against the backdrop of war, fate, and the nature of existence itself.

fields.title: Red Rising
fields.author: Pierce Brown
fields.description: Red Rising by Pierce Brown is a dystopian science fiction novel set on a future Mars, where society is divided into a rigid caste system based on colors. The story follows Darrow, a lowborn 'Red,' who works as a miner in the harsh Martian underworld, believing he is helping to terraform the planet for future generations. However, Darrow's world shatters when he discovers that the ruling 'Golds' have been living in luxury for generations, while the Reds have been exploited as slaves. Fueled by grief and rage after a personal tragedy, Darrow undergoes a dangerous transformation, infiltrating the Golds' elite society to seek vengeance and ignite a revolution.

fields.title: Feed
fields.author: MT Anderson
fields.description: Feed by M.T. Anderson is a satirical dystopian novel set in a future society where people have neural implants called 'feeds' that provide constant access to information, entertainment, and consumerism. The story follows Titus, a teenage boy, and his friends, who live in a world dominated by corporate control and overwhelming technology. When Titus meets Violet, a girl who resists the feed and is critical of its effects on society, he begins to question the nature of the feed and his own existence.

fields.title: Kala
fields.author: Colin Walsh
fields.description: Kala by Colin Walsh is a gripping and atmospheric novel that follows the life of a young woman named Kala, who lives in the remote and rugged landscape of Ireland. Struggling with the complexities of her past and the weight of family expectations, Kala is determined to forge her own path in a world that feels increasingly isolating. When she forms an unlikely bond with a mysterious outsider, their connection forces her to confront painful truths about herself, her relationships, and the choices that have shaped her life.

fields.title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
fields.author: Gabrielle Zevin
fields.description: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow by Gabrielle Zevin is a captivating novel that explores the intersection of love, friendship, and the world of video game development. The story follows Sam and Sadie, two childhood friends who reconnect years after a falling-out and form a creative partnership to develop a groundbreaking video game. As they navigate the challenges of the gaming industry, their relationship evolves, with themes of ambition, rivalry, and the complexities of their shared history influencing their journey.

fields.title: Norwegian Wood
fields.author: Haruki Murakami
fields.description: Norwegian Wood by Haruki Murakami is a poignant coming-of-age novel set in 1960s Tokyo, following the life of Toru Watanabe, a college student navigating love, loss, and identity. The novel begins with Toru reflecting on his college years after hearing the song 'Norwegian Wood' by The Beatles, which takes him back to his relationships with two very different women: Naoko, the fragile, emotionally troubled girlfriend of his late best friend, and Midori, a vibrant, independent classmate.

fields.title: The Bricks that Built the Houses
fields.author: Kae Tempest
fields.description: The Bricks That Built the Houses by Kae Tempest is a bold and introspective novel that explores the lives of a group of young people navigating the complexities of adulthood, identity, and relationships in contemporary London. The story is told from multiple perspectives, primarily focusing on Harry, a young man struggling with the weight of his past, and his connections with his close-knit circle of friends, including his sibling, their mother, and a lover named Iris. As the characters experience the turbulence of love, ambition, and personal reinvention, they confront the emotional and societal forces that shape their lives.

fields.title: Middlesex
fields.author: Jeffrey Eugenides
fields.description: Middlesex by Jeffrey Eugenides is a multi-generational family saga that tells the story of Cal Stephanides, an intersex person who was assigned female at birth but later identifies as male. The novel spans several decades, tracing Cal's complex journey of self-discovery while also exploring the history of her/his Greek-American family. Through a series of flashbacks, the book recounts the life of Cal's grandparents, the immigrant experience in America, and the unfolding of Cal's own personal identity from childhood to adulthood.

fields.title: Exciting Times
fields.author: Naoise Dolan
fields.description: Exciting Times by Naoise Dolan is a sharp, witty novel that follows the life of Ava, a young Irish woman who moves to Hong Kong to teach English. Ava's life becomes increasingly complicated as she enters a complicated, noncommittal romantic relationship with Julian, a wealthy English banker. However, things take a turn when she meets Edith, a smart, self-assured woman with whom she also forms a deep and complex connection. The novel explores Ava’s evolving relationships with both Julian and Edith, as well as her struggle to understand her own desires and emotional needs.

fields.title: Women Don't Owe You Pretty
fields.author: Florence Given
fields.description: Women Don't Owe You Pretty by Florence Given is a bold and empowering book that challenges the societal norms surrounding women's bodies, relationships, and self-worth. Written in a manifesto-like style, the book encourages women to reclaim their autonomy, reject the pressures of pleasing others, and embrace their own beauty and power. Florence Given blends personal anecdotes, social commentary, and feminist theory to deconstruct harmful ideas about beauty, love, and gender expectations, urging readers to stop apologizing for their existence and to prioritize their own happiness and well-being.

fields.title: The Van
fields.author: Roddy Doyle
fields.description: The Van by Roddy Doyle is a darkly comedic novel that follows the story of Jimmy Rabbitte Sr., a man in his late forties who has recently lost his job. In an effort to regain his sense of purpose, Jimmy teams up with his longtime friend, Bimbo, to open a fast food van selling fish and chips. Set against the backdrop of 1980s Dublin, the novel explores themes of friendship, economic hardship, and the challenges of middle age as the two men navigate the ups and downs of their new business venture.

fields.title: To the Lighthouse
fields.author: Virginia Woolf
fields.description: To the Lighthouse by Virginia Woolf is a modernist classic that explores the complexities of time, memory, and human relationships. Set in the Ramsay family's summer home on the Isle of Skye in Scotland, the novel centers on the interactions and inner lives of its characters over the course of a decade. At the heart of the story is Mrs. Ramsay, the matriarch, who embodies warmth and domestic harmony, and her husband, Mr. Ramsay, a philosopher absorbed in his intellectual pursuits. As the family navigates various joys and conflicts, the novel also examines the impact of war, aging, and unspoken desires.

fields.title: Emma
fields.author: Jane Austen
fields.description: Emma by Jane Austen is a witty and insightful novel that follows the life of Emma Woodhouse, a young, wealthy, and somewhat spoiled woman living in the small English village of Highbury. Confident in her matchmaking abilities, Emma takes it upon herself to arrange romantic relationships for others, particularly her friend Harriet Smith, who is a more humble and impressionable young woman. However, Emma's well-intentioned efforts at matchmaking often lead to misunderstandings, complications, and unintended consequences, forcing her to confront her own feelings and the complexities of love.

fields.title: The Pearl
fields.author: John Steinbeck
fields.description: The Pearl by John Steinbeck is a novella that tells the story of Kino, a poor pearl diver in a coastal village in Mexico, who discovers a large and valuable pearl. Kino hopes the pearl will bring a better life for his family, allowing him to provide education for his son, Coyotito, and improve their social status. However, the discovery of the pearl leads to unintended consequences, as Kino and his wife, Juana, are soon consumed by greed, envy, and violence. As they try to sell the pearl, the villagers' attitudes toward them change, and Kino's world unravels.

fields.title: Up at the Villa
fields.author: Somerset Maugham
fields.description: Up at the Villa by W. Somerset Maugham is a novel that explores themes of love, morality, and the complexity of human relationships. The story is set in post-World War II Italy, where the widowed and financially secure Mary Panton is staying in a beautiful villa. While there, she finds herself entangled in a whirlwind of emotions and moral dilemmas. After a chance encounter with an American named Rowley, she becomes romantically involved with him. However, Mary’s life takes an unexpected turn when she finds herself in a compromising situation that challenges her values and forces her to make difficult decisions.

fields.title: City of Bohane
fields.author: Kevin Barry
fields.description: The City of Bohane by Kevin Barry is a darkly atmospheric and vividly imaginative novel set in a dystopian future where the city of Bohane, a once-thriving Irish town, is now a gritty, decaying urban landscape ruled by gangs and a sense of lawlessness. The story follows the life of Logan, a charismatic but morally ambiguous leader of one of the city's most powerful gangs. As he faces both internal and external conflicts—rival gang leaders, personal betrayal, and his own complex emotions—Logan tries to maintain control of his domain while grappling with the ghosts of his past.

fields.title: Another Country
fields.author: James Baldwin
fields.description: Another Country by James Baldwin is a powerful and thought-provoking novel set in New York City in the 1950s. It explores the intersecting lives of a diverse group of characters, primarily focusing on the complex relationships between Rufus Scott, a troubled African American musician, and his friends and lovers. As the narrative unfolds, it delves deeply into issues of race, sexuality, identity, and the struggle for personal freedom. The novel examines the emotional and psychological toll of racism, love, and societal expectations as the characters grapple with their desires, heartbreak, and their attempts to break free from societal constraints.

fields.title: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
fields.author: Maya Angelou
fields.description: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings by Maya Angelou is an autobiographical novel that details the early years of the author's life, beginning with her childhood in the segregated South. The story follows Marguerite (Maya) Johnson, a young African American girl who faces numerous challenges, including racism, sexual abuse, and the instability of family life. As she grows up, Maya grapples with feelings of isolation, shame, and the desire to find her place in a world that often marginalizes her. The novel highlights the transformative power of literature, education, and self-expression as Maya learns to navigate these obstacles and embrace her identity.
